author: jeffrey.downard
title: Creating a Level Playing Field
description: Cómo construir la confianza en la gobernanza a la vez que se establece una mayor igualdad de condiciones para todos? Qué dApps son necesarias para los organismos administrativos?

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal seeks to solve the problem of lack of trust in governance by a dApp that tracks transactions between government agencies and individuals/businesses which partially aligns with the challenge goal but is not a foundational registry solution listed in the challenge.
The proposal could be improved by better articulating the value to Cardano ecosystem, providing key metrics and goals that align with the challenge and either selecting another challenge (Miscellaneous) or more closely aligning with this challenge's goals.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal articulates well feasibility in the areas of team composition, budget is broken down and reasonable (although percentage of project management seems high), realistic timetable and plan.

The proposal's feasibility could be improved by including evidence of experience (linkedin profile), resources required (web hosting costs), detailed technical explanation of the solution (particularly in the area of privacy concerns) and a challenges and risks section.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal includes a roadmap, milestones, time horizon and aclear understandable description of the targeted problem.
To improve the proposal include metrics/KPIs to measure proposal success and a detailed description of the solution that addresses the problem.

f6_assessments.q0: A dapp that helps countries live better would be great. However, the proposer didn't add enough details for me to understand what kind of dapp it  will be. I suggest to the proposer to be more specific on the problem the proposal is trying to solve. This will help the proposer be more precise on the dapp that will be created.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer should've add more information of what is being built. Building a dapp is vague to be feasible. I suggest to the proposer the be mor precise on the nature and fonctionalities of the dapp that they want to build.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal is missing a critical information to be easily auditable. First and foremost, the description of the dapp being built is too vague. The proposer can definitely improve on that. Then, the proposer can improve this proposal by adding strong KPIs that define success. Finally, the proposer should better describe the problem they are trying to solve, and the solution.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is quite interesting and meet the challenge problem. However, I think that you need to describe more your idea. How technically it is included in Cardano, which users will be able to use the Dapp. Will it be use by companies, by everyday people? Will your Dapp be multilanguage?
f6_assessments.q1:
Your idea, your planning and the experience of your team seems well describe. However, as I said I think the technical part need to be more describe.
You describe well the cost of every milestone of your planning but the associated costs seems sometimes underestimated like the development of the web sites and videos for 500$
You need to describe more the operation phase (cost and teams) and how your solution will earn incomes to operate. Phase 2 and 3 need to be more developed and how you will operate to make this Dapp used by many countries
f6_assessments.q2: You had no KPI to follow the development of your proposal. You need to describe a more how you will how the community can measure its development. There are many way to measure the progress of your plateform (number of connection, number of members, number of country or administration using it etc…)

f6_assessments.q0: Good problem identification. This is a matter of great concern in most developing countries. There are too many middlemen and payment of unofficial fees when dealing with the government. I think despite being a great proposal, it must focus on one region and with a big picture to expand after the first success story. There are geopolitical differences and benefit from the status quo this proposal seeks to solve. Kindly factor in those external threats as well.
f6_assessments.q1: Great project phases, the breakdown is detailed and practical. I think the team should have included metrics for measuring success. what language would be considered for building the Dapp, would it be opened source. I think the team must furnish some helpful information.
f6_assessments.q2: I think the budget might be small depending on the programing language for the Dapp. More details are needed on the DAPP and its development, features, and security, to ascertain the cost. The team should include audit process and document their activities as well.

f6_assessments.q0: The idea of providing a dApp to developing world governments that might help mitigate corruption is an intriguing one that fits very well in the nation building challenge. Bribery in particular is a prevalent problem in much of the developing world and governments making a good faith effort to prevent it might find such a tool very useful.
f6_assessments.q1: The team presented are very active in Catalyst and seem to have a strong knowledge base on these issues. My own expertise is centered more on the civic and policy side, and I'm definitely not qualified on the technical matters or their costs. However, their plan could use a little more detail. For example: Which developing countries are they considering for deployment ("developing countries" is an enormous category and there are big differences between, say, Burundi, Brazil, and UAE), and what kind of relationship do the proposers currently have with them that would ensure these governments would use the dApp? I'd also like to know more about how exactly Estonia and Switzerland's practices inform this idea. But overall, the timeline seems quite fair and it would be most enjoyable to see this idea deployed within a year, and how the selected governments make use of it.
f6_assessments.q2: This is where I worry a little. Considering that this team is requesting $28000, a reporting mechanism would make sense, so that the team could deliver reports on their progress and field questions from the community on a regular basis. I think this is especially important for dApps that are meant to serve as a sort of public good -- an important part of the Cardano mission -- and involves exchanges that could involve taxpayer money in countries where institutions may be suffering from failures in legitimacy. There needs to be some kind of ongoing open conversation with this project for it to ultimately achieve and deserve public trust. This is not to say that the underlying objective isn't strong. Only that the stakes are potentially rather high, and thus mechanisms for auditibility ought to be a high priority.
